sense.name: hit, collide, or attack
sense.commentary: Syntax includes: NP1[actor] STRIKE NP2[actor] NP1[agent] STRIKE NP2[patient] Includes: STRIKE BACK, STRIKE DOWN
sense.examples: He struck the table hard with his fists. Her car went out of control and struck an oncoming vehicle. They took the reed and struck him on his head. In 1979, the killer struck again, killing a couple in the park. Germany struck Poland in 1939 using gliders. The team struck back with vengeance. A strange sound struck my ears. The lightning struck down on the hikers. When he struck the middle C key, we heard 'bonggg' in front of us. Just when I entered, the clock struck midnight. The floods have struck the town on two other occasions. I am struck down with cold and dry cough. A devastating tornado struck the community resulting in the loss of life. A severe economic recession struck the state of Washington.

sense.name: cause to think or feel
sense.examples: He was fixing his bike when the thought struck him. It just struck me that I still owe you for the concert tickets. It also struck me odd that all itineraries had my new address on them. Doesn't this strike you as weird?

sense.name: come across something or discover
sense.examples: Have the Mars rovers struck water? The hikers finally struck the main path to the lake. We struck oil in our own back yard!

sense.name: achieve or attain something
sense.examples: After 2 failures, he struck success with his 3rd venture. The horse finally struck a pace. We turned to the traffic and struck the pose: right arm out, thumb up. Dell and Google struck a deal today.

sense.name: stop work
sense.examples: The workers were striking for a raise of 50 cents per day.

sense.name: remove; make void
sense.commentary: Includes: STRIKE DOWN, STRIKE OFF, STRIKE OUT
sense.examples: Please strike this remark from the record. Please strike my name off your mailing list. Latecomers' names will be struck out from the list. A federal judge in Philadelphia struck down the law in February 1999.

sense.name: make by stamping as in a coin
sense.examples: This coin struck under Tiberius in 15 or 16 CE. The city struck a medal in his honor.

sense.name: start something
sense.examples: He struck fire from the flintstones. He struck out on his own after becoming frustrated working with the system. The musicians struck up a tune. How do I strike up a conversation with complete strangers?

sense.name: STRIKE OUT-be put out of game or be unsuccessful
sense.examples: He struck out three batters to close the inning. The candidate struck out with his health care plan.

sense.name: idiomatic expressions
sense.commentary: Includes: STRIKE A BLOW, STRIKE A CHORD, STRIKE A NOTE, STRIKE HOME, STRIKE DUMB
sense.examples: The court ruling struck a blow at the old segration laws. The story struck a chord with the listeners. Her comments struck a sour note. I hope this message strikes home. The announcements struck us dumb.
